CHAPTER VIII

A Family Party

THEY found Lady Anne Percival in the midst of her (Percival) children, who all turned their healthy, rosy, intelligent faces towards the door, the moment that they heard their father's voice. Clarence Hervey was so much struck with the expression of happiness in Lady Anne's countenance, that he (Hervey) absolutely forgot to compare her (Anne) beauty with Lady Delacour's. Whether her (Anne) eyes were large or small, blue or hazel, he (Hervey) could not tell; nay, he (Hervey) might have been puzzled if he (Hervey) had been asked the colour of her (Anne) hair. Whether she (Anne) were handsome by the rules of art, he (Hervey) knew not; but he (Hervey) felt that she (Anne) had the essential charm of beauty, the power of prepossessing the heart immediately in her (Anne) favour. The effect of her (Anne) manners, like that of her (Anne) beauty, was rather to be felt than described. Every body was at ease in her (Anne) company, and none thought themselves called upon to admire her (Anne). To Clarence Hervey, who had been used to the brilliant and exigeante Lady Delacour, this respite from the fatigue of admiration was peculiarly agreeable. The unconstrained cheerfulness of Lady Anne Percival spoke a mind at ease, and immediately imparted happiness by exacting sympathy; but in Lady Delacour's wit and gaiety there was an appearance of art and effort, which often destroyed the pleasure that she (Delacour) wished to communicate. Mr Hervey was, perhaps unusually, disposed to reflection, by having just escaped from drowning; for he (Hervey) had made all these comparisons, and came to this conclusion, with the accuracy of a metaphysician, who has been accustomed to study cause and effect -- indeed there was no species of knowledge for which he (Hervey) had not taste and talents, though, to please fools, he (Hervey) too often affected `the bliss of ignorance.''

The children at Lady Anne Percival's happened to be looking at some gold fish, which were in a glass globe, and Dr X--, who was a general favourite with the younger as well as with the elder part of the family, was seized upon the moment he (Hervey) entered the room: a pretty little girl of five years old took him (Hervey) prisoner by the flap of the coat, whilst two of her (girl) brothers assailed him (Hervey) with questions about the ears, eyes, and fins of fishes. One of the little boys filliped the glass globe, and observed, that the fish immediately came to the surface of the water, and seemed to hear the noise very quickly; but his (Hervey) brother doubted whether the fish heard the noise, and remarked, that they might be disturbed by seeing or feeling the motion of the water, when the glass was struck.

Dr X-- observed, that this was a very learned dispute, and that the question had been discussed by no less a person than the Abbé Nollet; and he (Hervey) related some of the ingenious experiments tried by that gentleman, to decide whether fishes can or cannot hear. Whilst the doctor was speaking, Clarence Hervey was struck with the intelligent countenance of one of the little auditors, a girl of about ten or twelve years old; he (Hervey) was surprised to discover in her (girl) features, though not in their expression, a singular resemblance to Lady Delacour. He (Hervey) remarked this to Mr Percival, and the child, who overheard him (Percival), blushed as red as scarlet. Dinner was announced at this instant, and Clarence Hervey thought no more of the circumstance, attributing the girl's blush to confusion at being looked at so earnestly. One of the little boys whispered as they were going down to dinner,

``Helena, I do believe that this is the good-natured gentleman who went out of the path to make room for us, instead of running over us as the other man did.'' (the boys)
The children agreed that Clarence Hervey certainly was the good-natured gentleman, and upon the strength of this observation, one of the boys posted himself next to Clarence at dinner, and by all the little playful manoeuvres in his (Clarence) power endeavoured to show his (Clarence) gratitude, and to cultivate a friendship which had been thus auspiciously commenced. Mr Hervey, who piqued himself upon being able always to suit his (Hervey) conversation to his (Hervey) companions, distinguished himself at dinner by an account of the Chinese fighting-bird, from which he (Hervey) passed to the various ingenious methods of fishing practised by the Russian Cossacks. From modern he (Hervey) went to ancient fish, and he (Hervey) talked of that which was so much admired by the Roman epicures for exhibiting a succession of beautiful colours whilst it is dying; and which was, upon that account, always suffered to die in the presence of the guests, as part of the entertainment -- Clarence was led on by the questions of the children from fishes to birds; he (Clarence) spoke of the Roman aviaries, which were so constructed as to keep from the sight of the prisoners that they contained, `the fields, woods, and every object which might remind them of their former liberty.'' -- From birds he (Clarence) was going on to beasts, when he (Clarence) was nearly struck dumb by the forbidding severity with which an elderly lady, who sat opposite to him (Clarence), fixed her (lady) eyes upon him (Clarence). He (Clarence) had not, till this instant, paid the smallest attention to her (lady); but her (lady) stern countenance was now so strongly contrasted with the approving looks of the children who sat next to her (lady), that he (Clarence) could not help remarking it. He (Clarence) asked her (lady) to do him (Clarence) the honour to drink a glass of wine with him (Clarence). She (lady) declined doing him (Clarence) that honour; observing that she (lady) never drank more than one glass of wine at dinner, and that she (lady) had just taken one with Mr Percival. Her (lady) manner was well-bred, but haughty in the extreme; and she (lady) was so passionate, that her (lady) anger sometimes conquered even her (lady) politeness. Her (lady) dislike to Clarence Hervey was apparent, even in her (lady) silence.
``If the old gentlewoman has taken an antipathy to me at first sight, I cannot help it,'' (unknown)

One night, at a select party at Lady Delacour's, a Spanish gentleman was amusing the company with some anecdotes, to prove the extraordinary passion which some of his (gentleman) countrymen formerly showed for the game of chess. He (gentleman) mentioned families, in which unfinished games, bequeathed by will, had descended from father to son, and where victory was doubtful for upwards of a century.

Mr Hervey observed, that gaining a battle was, at that time, so common to the court of Spain, that a victory at chess seemed to confer more éclat; for that an abbé, by losing adroitly a game at chess to the Spanish minister, obtained a cardinal's hat.

CHAPTER X

The Mysterious Boudoir

ACCUSTOMED to study human nature, Dr X-- had acquired peculiar sagacity in judging of character. Notwithstanding the address with which Lady Delacour concealed the real motives for her (Delacour) apparently thoughtless conduct, he (character) quickly discovered that the hatred of Mrs Luttridge was her (Luttridge) ruling passion. Above nine years of continual warfare had exasperated the tempers of both parties, and no opportunities of manifesting their mutual antipathy were ever neglected. Extravagantly as Lady Delacour loved admiration, the highest possible degree of positive praise was insipid to her (Delacour) taste, if it did not imply some superiority over the woman whom she (Delacour) considered as a perpetual rival.

Now it had been said by the coachmaker, that Mrs Luttridge would sport a most elegant new vis-à-vis on the king's birthday. Lady Delacour was immediately ambitious to outshine her (Delacour) in equipage; and it was this paltry ambition that made her (Delacour) condescend to all the meanness of the transaction by which she (Delacour) obtained Miss Portman's draft, and Clarence Hervey's two hundred guineas. The great, the important day, at length arrived -- her (Delacour) ladyship's triumph in the morning at the drawing-room was complete. Mrs Luttridge's horses were nothing, absolutely nothing, in comparison with Lady Delacour's: her (Delacour) ladyship enjoyed the full exultation of vanity; and at night she (Delacour) went in high spirits to the ball.

' CHAPTER XI

Difficulties

BEFORE he (Clarence) left town, Dr X-- called in Berkeley-square, to see Lady Delacour; he (Clarence) found that she (Delacour) was out of all immediate danger. Miss Portman was sorry that he (Clarence) was obliged to quit her (Portman) at this time, but she (Portman) felt the necessity for his (Clarence) going; he (Clarence) was sent for to attend Mr Horton, an intimate friend of his (Clarence), a gentleman of great talents, and of the most active benevolence, who had just been seized with a violent fever, in consequence of his (Clarence) exertions in saving the poor inhabitants of a village in his (Clarence) neighbourhood from the effect of a dreadful fire, which broke out in the middle of the night.

The Macaw

Lady Delacour was surprised by the sudden entrance of Marriott, and her (Marriott) macaw. The chain which held the bird Marriott put into her (Marriott) ladyship's hand without being able to say any thing more than,

``Do what you please, my lady, with it -- and with me.'' (ladyship)

Pacified by this submission, Lady Delacour granted Marriott's pardon, and she (Marriott) most sincerely rejoiced at this reconciliation.

The next day Belinda asked the dowager Lady Boucher, who was going to a bird-fancier's, to take her (Belinda) with her (Belinda), in hopes that she (Belinda) might be able to meet with some bird more musical than a macaw, to console Marriott for the loss of her (Marriott) screaming favourite. Lady Delacour commissioned Miss Portman to go to any price she (Portman) pleased.

``If I were able, I would accompany you myself, my dear, for poor Marriott's sake, though I would almost as soon go to the Augean stable.'' (Mons)

There was a bird-fancier in High Holborn, who had bought several of the hundred and eighty beautiful birds, which, as the newspapers of the day advertised, had been `collected, after great labour and expense, by Mons Marten and Co. for the Republican Museum at Paris, and lately landed out of the French brig Urselle, taken on her (Portman) voyage from Cayenne to Brest, by His (Marten) Majesty's Ship Unicorn.''

When Lady Boucher and Belinda arrived at this bird-fancier's, they were long in doubt to which of the feathered beauties they should give the preference. Whilst the dowager was descanting upon their various perfections, a lady and three children came in; she (lady) immediately attracted Belinda's attention, by her (lady) likeness to Clarence Hervey's description of Lady Anne Percival -- it was Lady Anne, as Lady Boucher, who was slightly acquainted with her (Boucher), informed Belinda in a whisper.

The children were soon eagerly engaged looking at the birds.

``Miss Portman,'' (Lady Boucher)
said Lady Boucher, `as Lady Delacour is so far from well, and wishes to have a bird that will not make any noise in the house, suppose you were to buy for Mrs Marriott this beautiful pair of green parroquets; or stay, a goldfinch is not very noisy, and here is one that can play a thousand pretty tricks. Pray, sir, make it draw up water in its little bucket for us.''

``Oh, mamma!'' (the boys)
said one of the little boys, `this is the very thing that is mentioned in Bewick's History of Birds. Pray look at this goldfinch, Helena, now it is drawing up its little bucket -- but where is Helena? here's room for you, Helena.''

``Can I speak a few words to you?'' (Helena/Miss Helena)
said Helena.

``Is my mamma better?'' (she)

(Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)

(Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)

``This is a bird of good omen,'' (she)

CHAPTER XIII

Sortes Virgilianæ

WHEN Belinda got home, Lady Delacour was busy in the library looking over a collection of French plays with the ci-devant Count de N--; a gentleman who possessed such singular talents for reading dramatic compositions, that many people declared that they would rather hear him (gentleman) read a play than see it performed at the theatre. Even those who were not judges of his (gentleman) merit, and who had little taste for literature, crowded to hear him (gentleman), because it was the fashion. Lady Delacour engaged him (gentleman) for a reading party at her (Delacour) house, and he (gentleman) was consulting with her (Delacour) what play would be most amusing to his (gentleman) audience.

If it has not a voice like the macaw I shall be satisfied; but even if it be the bird of paradise, I question whether Marriott will like it as well as its screaming predecessor.''

He (Hervey) frankly confessed, that when he (Hervey) was first acquainted with her (Delacour) ladyship, he (Hervey) had looked upon her (Delacour) merely as a dissipated woman of fashion, and he (Hervey) had considered only his (Hervey) own amusement in cultivating her (Delacour) society:

``s?'' (people)

CHAPTER XIV

The Exhibition

(Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)

``Miss Portman fears that my husband is growing too fond of me: she (Portman) says, he (husband) has been very attentive to me of late. CHAPTER XV

Jealousy

``Crescent, Bath, July -- Wednesday.

``MY DEAR NIECE,

``I RECEIVED safely the bank notes for my two hundred guineas, enclosed in your last. But you should never trust unnecessarily in this manner to the post -- always, when you are obliged to send bank notes by post, cut them in two, and send half by one post and half by another. This is what is done by all prudent people. Prudence, whether in trifles or in matters of consequence, can be learned only by experience -LRB-which is often too dearly bought-RRB-, or by listening, which costs nothing, to the suggestions of those who have a thorough knowledge of the world.

``A report has just reached me concerning you and a certain lord, which gives me the most heartfelt concern. I always knew, and told you, that you were a great favourite with the person in question. I depended on your prudence, delicacy, and principles, to understand this hint properly, and I trusted that you would conduct yourself accordingly. It is too plain, -LRB-from the report alluded to,-RRB- that there has been some misconduct or mismanagement somewhere. The misconduct I cannot -- the mismanagement I must, attribute to you, my dear; for let a man's admiration for any woman be ever so great, unless she (woman) suffer herself to be dazzled by vanity, or unless she (woman) be naturally of an inconsiderate temper, she (woman) can surely prevent his (man) partiality from becoming so glaring as to excite envy: envy is always to be dreaded by handsome young women, as being, sooner or later, infallibly followed by scandal. Of this, I fear, you have not been sufficiently aware and you see the consequences -- consequences which, to a female of genuine delicacy or of real good sense, must be extremely alarming. Men of contracted minds and cold tempers, who are absolutely incapable of feeling generous passion for our sex, are often unaccountably ambitious to gain the reputation of being well with any woman whose beauty, accomplishments, or connexions, may have brought her (woman) into fashion. Whatever affection may be pretended, this is frequently the ultimate and sole object of these selfish creatures. Whether or not the person I have in my eye deserve to be included in this class, I will not presume positively to determine; but you, who have personal opportunities of observation, may decide this point -LRB-if you have any curiosity on the subject-RRB- by observing whether he (you) most affects to pay his (you) devoirs to you in public or in private. If the latter be the case, it is the most dangerous; because a man even of the most contracted understanding has always sense or instinct enough to feel that the slightest taint in the reputation of the woman who is, or who is to be, his (man) wife, would affect his (man) own private peace, or his (man) honour in the eyes of the world. A husband who has in a first marriage been, as it is said, in constant fear both of matrimonial subjugation and disgrace, would, in his (man) choice of a second lady, be peculiarly nice, and probably tardy. Any degree of favour that might have been shown him (man), any report that may have been raised, and above all, any restraint he (man) might feel himself under from implied engagement, or from the discovery or reputation of superior understanding and talents in the object beloved, would operate infallibly against her (lady), to the confusion of all her (lady) plans, and the ruin at once of her (lady) reputation, her (lady) peace of mind, and her (lady) hopes of an establishment. Nay, supposing the best that could possibly happen -- that, after playing with the utmost dexterity this desperate game, the pool were absolutely your own; yet, if there were any suspicions of unfair play buzzed about amongst the by-standers, you would not in the main be a gainer; for my dear, without character, what is even wealth, or all that wealth can bestow? I do not mean to trouble you with stale wise sayings, which young people hate; nor musty morality, which is seldom fit for use in the world, or which smells too much of books to be brought into good company. This is not my way of giving advice; but I only beg you to observe what actually passes before your eyes in the circle in which we live. Ladies of the best families, with rank and fortune, and beauty and fashion, and every thing in their favour, cannot -LRB-as yet in this country-RRB- dispense with the strictest observance of the rules of virtue and decorum. Some have fancied themselves raised so high above the vulgar as to be in no danger from the thunder and lightning of public opinion; but these ladies in the clouds have found themselves mistaken -- they have been blasted, and have fallen nobody knows where! What is become of Lady --, and the Countess of --, and others I could mention, who were as high as envy could look? I remember seeing the Countess of --, who was then the most beautiful creature my eyes ever beheld, and the most admired that ever was heard of, come into the Opera-house, and sit the whole night in her (Countess) box without any woman's speaking or courtesying to her (Countess), or taking any more notice of her (Countess) than you would of a post, or a beggar-woman. Even a coronet cannot protect a woman, you see, from disgrace: if she (woman) falls, she (woman) and it, and all together, are trampled under foot. But why should I address all this to my dear niece? Whither have the terror and confusion I was thrown into by this strange report about you and Lord -- led me? And yet one cannot be too cautious -- ``Ce n'est que le premier mot qui coute'' -- Scandal never stops after the first word, unless she (Portman) be instantly gagged by a dexterous hand. Nothing shall be wanting on my part, but you alone are the person who can do any thing effectual. Do not imagine that I would have you quit Lady --, that is the first idea, I know, that will come into your silly little head, but put it out directly. If you were upon this attack to quit the field of battle, you yield the victory to your enemies. To leave Lady --'s house would be folly and madness. As long as she (Lady) is your friend, or appears such, all is safe; but any coolness on her (Lady) part would, in the present circumstances, be death to your reputation. And, even if you were to leave her (Lady) on the best terms possible, the malicious world would say that you left her (Lady) on the worst, and would assign as a reason the report alluded to. People who have not yet believed it would then conclude that it must be true; and thus by your cowardice you would furnish an incontrovertible argument against your innocence. I therefore desire that you will not, upon any account, think of coming home to me at present; indeed, I hope your own good sense would prevent you from wishing it, after the reasons that I have given. Far from quitting Lady -- from false delicacy, it is your business, from consideration for her (Lady) peace, as well as your own, to redouble your attentions to her (Lady) in private, and, above all things, to appear as much as possible with her (Lady) in public. I am glad to hear her (Lady) health is so far re-established, that she (Lady) can appear again in public; her (Lady) spirits, as you may hint, will be the better for a little amusement. Luckily, you have it completely in your power to convince her (Lady) and all the world of the correctness of your mind. I believe I certainly should have fainted, my dear, when I first heard this shocking report, if I had not just afterward received a letter from Sir Philip Baddely which revived me. His (Baddely) proposal at this crisis for you, my dear, is a charming thing. You have nothing to do but to encourage his (Baddely) addresses immediately, -- the report dies away of itself, and all is just as your best friends wish. Such an establishment for you, my dear, is indeed beyond their most sanguine expectations. Sir Philip hints in his (Philip) letter, that my influence might be wanting with you in his (Philip) favour; but this surely cannot be. As I have told him (Philip), he (Philip) has merely mistaken becoming female reserve for a want of sensibility on your part, which would be equally unnatural and absurd. Do you know, my dear, that Sir Philip Baddely has an estate of fifteen thousand a-year in Wiltshire? and his (Baddely) uncle Barton's estate in Norfolk will, in due time, pay his (Baddely) debts. Then, as to family -- look in the lists of baronets in your pocket-book; and surely, my love, an old baronetage in actual possession is worth something more than the reversion of a new coronet; supposing that such a thing could properly be thought of, which Heaven forbid! So I see no possible objection to Sir Philip, my dear Belinda! and I am sure you have too much candour and good sense to make any childish or romantic difficulties. Sir Philip, is not, I know, a man of what you call genius. So much the better, my dear -- those men of genius are dangerous husbands; they have so many dislikes and eccentricities, there is no managing them, though they are mighty pleasant men in company to enliven conversation; for example, your favourite, Clarence Hervey. I cannot conceive that a niece of mine could degrade herself by a mean prepossession for a man who has never made any declaration of his (man) attachment to her (niece), and who, I am sure, feels no such attachment. If you have any sense or spirit, I have said enough. So adieu! -- Let me hear, by return of the post, that every thing is going on as it should do. CHAPTER XVI

Domestic Happiness

THERE was an air of benevolence and perfect sincerity in the politeness with which Lady Anne Percival received Belinda that was peculiarly agreeable to her (Belinda) agitated and harassed mind.

``You see, Lady Anne,'' (Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)

``She (Anne) must have had extraordinary prudence,'' (Lady Anne/Lady Anne Percival/Percival)

In fact, it was known and believed only by those who had been prejudiced by the malice or folly of Sir Philip Baddely. ``I have, therefore,'' (Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)

``P.S.. If you return directly to Lady Delacour's, and marry Sir Philip Baddely, I will forgive the past.'' (Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)

The regret which Belinda felt at having grievously offended her (Belinda) aunt was somewhat alleviated by the reflection that she (Belinda) had acted with integrity and prudence. Thrown off her (Belinda) guard by anger, Mrs Stanhope had inadvertently furnished her (Stanhope) niece with the best possible reasons against following her (Stanhope) advice with regard to Sir Philip Baddely, by stating that her (Stanhope) sister and cousins, who had married with mercenary views, had made themselves miserable, and had shown their aunt neither gratitude nor respect.

The tranquillity of Belinda's mind was gradually restored by the society that she (Belinda) enjoyed at Oakly-park. She (Belinda) found herself in the midst of a large and cheerful family, with whose domestic happiness she (Belinda) could not forbear to sympathize. There was an affectionate confidence, an unconstrained gaiety in this house, which forcibly struck her (Belinda), from its contrast with what she (Belinda) had seen at Lady Delacour's. She (Delacour) perceived that between Mr Percival and Lady Anne there was a union of interests, occupations, taste, and affection. She (Anne) was at first astonished by the openness with which they talked of their affairs in her (Anne) presence; that there were no family secrets, nor any of those petty mysteries which arise from a discordance of temper or struggle for power. In conversation, every person expressed without constraint their wishes and opinions; and wherever these differed, reason and the general good were the standards to which they appealed. The elder and younger part of the family were not separated from each other; even the youngest child in the house seemed to form part of the society, to have some share and interest in the general occupations or amusements. The children were treated neither as slaves nor as playthings, but as reasonable creatures; and the ease with which they were managed, and with which they managed themselves, surprised Belinda; for she (Belinda) heard none of that continual lecturing which goes forward in some houses, to the great fatigue and misery of all the parties concerned, and of all the spectators. Without force or any factitious excitements, the taste for knowledge, and the habits of application, were induced by example, and confirmed by sympathy. Mr Percival was a man of science and literature, and his (Percival) daily pursuits and general conversation were in the happiest manner instructive and interesting to his (Percival) family. His (Percival) knowledge of the world, and his (Percival) natural gaiety of disposition, rendered his (Percival) conversations not only useful, but in the highest degree amusing. From the merest trifles he (Percival) could lead to some scientific fact, some happy literary allusion, or philosophical investigation.

Lady Anne Percival had, without any pedantry or ostentation, much accurate knowledge, and a taste for literature, which made her (Percival) the chosen companion of her (Percival) husband's understanding, as well as of his (husband) heart. He (husband) was not obliged to reserve his (husband) conversation for friends of his (husband) own sex, nor was he (husband) forced to seclude himself in the pursuit of any branch of knowledge; the partner of his (husband) warmest affections was also the partner of his (husband) most serious occupations; and her (Percival) sympathy and approbation, and the daily sense of her (Percival) success in the education of their children, inspired him (husband) with a degree of happy social energy, unknown to the selfish solitary votaries of avarice and ambition.

In this large and happy family there was a variety of pursuits. One of the boys was fond of chemistry, another of gardening; one of the daughters had a talent for painting, another for music; and all their acquirements and accomplishments contributed to increase their mutual happiness, for there was no envy or jealousy amongst them.

Those who unfortunately have never enjoyed domestic happiness, such as we have just described, will perhaps suppose the picture to be visionary and romantic; there are others -- it is hoped many others -- who will feel that it is drawn from truth and real life. Tastes that have been vitiated by the stimulus of dissipation might, perhaps, think these simple pleasures insipid.

Every body must ultimately judge of what makes them happy, from the comparison of their own feelings in different situations. Belinda was convinced by this comparison, that domestic life was that which could alone make her (Belinda) really and permanently happy. She (Belinda) missed none of the pleasures, none of the gay company, to which she (Belinda) had been accustomed at Lady Delacour's. She (Belinda) was conscious, at the end of each day, that it had been agreeably spent; yet there were no extraordinary exertions made to entertain her (Belinda); every thing seemed in its natural course, and so did her (Belinda) mind. Where there was so much happiness, no want of what is called pleasure was ever experienced. She (Belinda) had not been at Oakly-park a week before she (Belinda) forgot that it was within a few miles of Harrowgate, and she (Belinda) never once recollected her (Belinda) vicinity to this fashionable water-drinking place for a month afterward.

``Impossible!'' (some ladies)
some young ladies will exclaim. We hope others will feel that it was perfectly natural. But to deal fairly with our readers, we must not omit to mention a certain Mr Vincent, who came to Oakly-park during the first week of Belinda's visit, and who stayed there during the whole succeeding month of felicity. Mr Vincent was a creole; he (Vincent) was about two-and-twenty: his (Vincent) person and manners were striking and engaging; he (Vincent) was tall, and remarkably handsome; he (Vincent) had large dark eyes, an aquiline nose, fine hair, and a manly sunburnt complexion; his (Vincent) countenance was open and friendly, and when he (Vincent) spoke upon any interesting subject, it lighted up, and became full of fire and animation. He (Vincent) used much gesture in conversation; he (Vincent) had not the common manners of young men who are, or who aim at being thought, fashionable, but he (Vincent) was perfectly at ease in company, and all that was uncommon about him (Vincent) appeared foreign. He (Vincent) had a frank, ardent temper, incapable of art or dissimulation, and so unsuspicious of all mankind, that he (Vincent) could scarcely believe falsehood existed in the world, even after he (Vincent) had himself been its dupe. He (Vincent) was in extreme astonishment at the detection of any species of baseness in a gentleman; for he (gentleman) considered honour and generosity as belonging indefeasibly, if not exclusively, to the privileged orders. His (gentleman) notions of virtue were certainly aristocratic in the extreme, but his (gentleman) ambition was to entertain such only as would best support and dignify an aristocracy. His (gentleman) pride was magnanimous, not insolent; and his (gentleman) social prejudices were such as, in some degree, to supply the place of the power and habit of reasoning, in which he (gentleman) was totally deficient. One principle of philosophy he (gentleman) practically possessed in perfection; he (gentleman) enjoyed the present, undisturbed by any unavailing regret for the past, or troublesome solicitude about the future. All the goods of life he (gentleman) tasted with epicurean zest; all the evils he (gentleman) bore with stoical indifference. The mere pleasure of existence seemed to keep him (gentleman) in perpetual good humour with himself and others; and his (gentleman) never-failing flow of animal spirits exhilarated even the most phlegmatic. To persons of a cold and reserved temper he (gentleman) sometimes appeared rather too much of an egotist: for he (gentleman) talked with fluent enthusiasm of the excellent qualities and beauties of whatever he (gentleman) loved, whether it were his (gentleman) dog, his (gentleman) horse, or his (gentleman) country: but this was not the egotism of vanity; it was the overflowing of an affectionate heart, confident of obtaining sympathy from his (gentleman) fellow-creatures, because conscious of feeling it for all that existed.

He (gentleman) was as grateful as he (gentleman) was generous; and though high-spirited and impatient of restraint, he (gentleman) would submit with affectionate gentleness to the voice of a friend, or listen with deference to the counsel of those in whose superior judgment he (counsel) had confidence. Gratitude, respect, and affection, all conspired to give Mr Percival the strongest power over his (Percival) soul. Mr Percival had been a guardian and a father to him (Percival). His (Percival) own father, an opulent merchant, on his (Percival) death-bed requested that his (Percival) son, who was then about eighteen, might be immediately sent to England for the advantages of a European education. Mr Percival, who had a regard for the father, arising from circumstances which it is not here necessary to explain, accepted the charge of young Vincent, and managed so well, that his (Vincent) ward when he (Vincent) arrived at the age of twenty-one did not feel relieved from any restraint. On the contrary, his (Vincent) attachment to his (Vincent) guardian increased from that period, when the laws gave him (Vincent) full command over his (Vincent) fortune and his (Vincent) actions. Mr Vincent had been at Harrowgate for some time before Mr Percival came into the country; but as soon as he (Percival) heard of Mr Percival's arrival, he (Percival) left half finished a game of billiards, of which, by-the-bye, he (Percival) was extremely fond, to pay his (Percival) respects at Oakly-park. CHAPTER XVII

Rights of Woman

BELINDA was alone, and reading, when Mrs Freke dashed into the room.

``How do, dear creature?'' (she)
cried she (Freke), stepping up to her (Freke), and shaking hands with her (Freke) boisterously --
``How do? -- Glad to see you, faith! -- Been long here? -- Tremendously hot to-day!'' (her)

She (Freke) flung herself upon the sofa beside Belinda, threw her (Belinda) hat upon the table, and then continued speaking.

``And how d'ye go on here, poor child? -- Gad! I'm glad you're alone -- expected to find you encompassed by a whole host of the righteous. Give me credit for my courage in coming to deliver you out of their hands. Luttridge and I had such compassion upon you, when we heard you were close prisoner here! I swore to set the distressed damsel free, in spite of all the dragons in Christendom; so let me carry you off in triumph in my unicorn, and leave these good people to stare when they come home from their sober walk, and find you gone. There's nothing I like so much as to make good people stare -- I hope you're of my way o' thinking -- you don't look as if you were, though; but I never mind young ladies' looks -- always give the lie to their thoughts. Now we talk o'looks -- never saw you look so well in my life -- as handsome as an angel! And so much the better for me. Do you know, I've a bet of twenty guineas on your head -- on your face, I mean. There's a young bride at Harrowgate, Lady H--, they're all mad about her (Lady); the men swear she (Lady)'s the handsomest woman in England, and I swear I know one ten times as handsome. They've dared me to make good my word, and I've pledged myself to produce my beauty at the next ball, and to pit her (Lady) against their belle for any money. Most votes carry it. I'm willing to double my bet since I've seen you again. Come, had not we best be off? Now don't refuse me and make speeches -- you know that's all nonsense -- I'll take all the blame upon myself.'' (Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)

CHAPTER XX

Reconciliation

``My friend, Dr X--,'' (he)
said he (writer), `divides mankind into three classes: those who learn from the experience of others -- they are happy men; those who learn from their own experience -- they are wise men; and, lastly, those who learn neither from their own nor from other people's experience -- they are fools. This class is by far the largest. I am content,'' continued Clarence, `to be in the middle class -- perhaps you will say because I cannot be in the first: however, were it in my power to choose my own character, I should, forgive me the seeming vanity of the speech, still be content to remain in my present station upon this principle -- the characters of those who are taught by their own experience must be progressive in knowledge and virtue. Those who learn from the experience of others may become stationary, because they must depend for their progress on the experiments that we brave volunteers, at whose expense they are to live and learn, are pleased to try. There may be much safety in thus snugly fighting, or rather seeing the battle of life, behind the broad shield of a stouter warrior; yet it seems to me to be rather an ignominious than an enviable situation.

``Our friend, Dr X--, would laugh at my insisting upon being amongst the class of learners by their own experience. He (friend) would ask me, whether it be the ultimate end of my philosophy to try experiments, or to be happy. And what answer should I make? I have none ready. Common sense stares me in the face, and my feelings, even at this instant, alas! confuse my system. I shall pay too dear yet for some of my experiments.

``Sois grand homme, et sois malheureux,'' (unknown)
is, I am afraid, the law of nature, or rather the decree of the world. Helena

CHAPTER XXII

A Spectre

THE surgeon who was to attend Lady Delacour was prevented from going to her (Delacour) on the day appointed; he (surgeon) was one of the surgeons of the queen's household, and his (surgeon) attendance was required at the palace. This delay was extremely irksome to Lady Delacour, who had worked up her (Delacour) courage to the highest point, but who had not prepared herself to endure suspense. She (Delacour) spent nearly a week at Twickenham in this anxious state, and Belinda observed that she (Belinda) every day became more and more thoughtful and reserved. She (Belinda) seemed as if she (Belinda) had some secret subject of meditation, from which she (Belinda) could not bear to be distracted. When Helena was present, she (Helena) exerted herself to converse in her (Helena) usual sprightly strain; but as soon as she (Helena) could escape, as she (Helena) thought, unobserved, she (Helena) would shut herself up in her (Helena) own apartment, and remain there for hours.

``I wish to Heaven, Miss Portman,'' (Marriott/Mrs Marriott)
said Marriott, coming one morning into her (Marriott) room with a portentous face,
``I wish to Heaven, ma'am, that you could any way persuade my lady not to spend so many hours of the day and night as she (lady) does in reading those methodistical books that she (lady) keeps to herself! -- I am sure that they do her (lady) no good, but a great deal of harm, especially now when her (lady) spirits should be kept up as much as possible. I am sensible, ma'am, that `tis those books that have made my lady melancholy of a sudden. Ma'am, my lady has let drop very odd hints within these two or three days, and she (lady) speaks in a strange disconnected sort of style, and at times I do not think she (lady) is quite right in her (lady) head.'' (Marriott/Mrs Marriott)

When Belinda questioned Marriott more particularly about the strange hints which her (Belinda) lady had let fall, she (Belinda) with looks of embarrassment and horror declined repeating the words that had been said to her (Belinda); yet persisted in asserting that Lady Delacour had been very strange for these two or three days.

``And I'm sure, ma'am, you'd be shocked if you were to see my lady in a morning, when she (lady) wakens, or rather when I first go into the room -- for, as to wakening, that's out of the question. I am certain she (lady) does not sleep during the whole night. You'll find, ma'am, it is as I tell you, those books will quite turn her (lady) poor head, and I wish they were burnt. I know the mischief that the same sort of things did to a poor cousin of my own, who was driven to melancholy mad by a methodist preacher, and came to an untimely end. Oh, ma'am! if you knew as much as I do, you'd be as much alarmed for my lady as I am.'' (Marriott/Mrs Marriott)

It was impossible to prevail upon Marriott to explain herself more distinctly. The only circumstances that could be drawn from her (Marriott) seemed to Belinda so trifling as to be scarcely worth mentioning. For instance, that Lady Delacour, contrary to Marriott's advice, had insisted on sleeping in a bedchamber upon the ground floor, and had refused to let a curtain be put up before a glass door that was at the foot of her (Delacour) bed. ``When I offered to put up the curtain, ma``am,'' said Marriot, `my lady said she (lady) liked the moonlight, and that she (lady) would not have it put up till the fine nights were over. Now, Miss Portman, to hear my lady talk of the moon, and moonlights, and liking the moon, is rather extraordinary and unaccountable; for I never heard her (lady) say any thing of the sort in her (lady) life before; I question whether she (lady) ever knew there was a moon or not from one year's end to another. But they say the moon has a great deal to do with mad people; and, from my own experience, I'm perfectly sensible, ma'am, it had in my cousin's case; for, before he (cousin) came to the worst, he (cousin) took a prodigious fancy to the moon, and was always for walking by moonlight, and talking to one of the beauty of the moon, and such melancholy nonsense, ma

``am.'' (Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)

Belinda could not forbear smiling at the melancholy nonsense; though she (Belinda) was inclined to be of Marriott's opinion about the methodistical books, and she (Marriott) determined to talk to Lady Delacour on the subject. The moment that she (Delacour) made the attempt, her (Delacour) ladyship, commanding her (Delacour) countenance, with her (Delacour) usual ability, replied only by cautious, cold monosyllables, and changed the conversation as soon as she (Delacour) could.

At night, when they were retiring to rest, Marriott, as she (Marriott) lighted them to their rooms, observed that she (Marriott) was afraid her (Marriott) lady would suffer from sleeping in so cold a bedchamber, and Belinda pressed her (Belinda) friend to change her (Belinda) apartment.

``No, my dear,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)
replied Lady Delacour, calmly.

There is a certain class of people, who are incapable of generous confidence in their equals, but who are disposed to yield implicit credit to the underhand information of mean emissaries. Through the medium of Champfort and the stupid maid, Mrs Freke had learned a confused story of a man's footsteps having been heard in Lady Delacour's boudoir, of his (man) being let in by Marriott secretly, of his (man) having remained locked up there for several hours, and of the maid's having been turned away, merely because she (maid) innocently went to open the door whilst the gentleman was in concealment. The desire of revenging herself upon Miss Portman, for having declined her (Portman) civilities at Harrowgate, had also a powerful influence in stimulating her (Portman) malicious activity. She (Portman) knew that if it were proved that Belinda was the confidante of Lady Delacour's intrigues, her (Delacour) reputation must be materially injured, and that the Percivals would then be as desirous to break off as they now were anxious to promote the match with Mr Vincent. Charmed with this hope of a double triumph, the vindictive lady commenced her (lady) operations, nor was she (lady) ashamed to descend to the character of a spy. The general and convenient name of frolic, she (lady) thought, would cover every species of meanness. She (lady) swore that `it was charming fun to equip herself at night in men's clothes, and to sally forth to reconnoitre the motions of the enemy.''

CHAPTER XXIII

The Chaplain

IN some minds, emotions of joy are always connected with feelings of benevolence and generosity. Lady Delacour's heart expanded with the sensations of friendship and gratitude, now that she (Delacour) was relieved from those fears by which she (Delacour) had so long been oppressed.

``My dear daughter,'' (she)
said she (Delacour) to Helena, `have you at this instant any wish that I can gratify? -- Ask any thing you please, the fairy Goodwill shall contrive to get it for you in a trice. You have thought of a wish at this moment, I know, by your eyes, by your blush. Nay, do not hesitate. Do you doubt me because I do not appear before you in the shape of a little ugly woman, like Cinderella's godmother? or do you despise me because you do not see a wand waving in my hand? --
``Ah, little skilled of fairy lore!'' (I)
know that I am in possession of a talisman that can command more than ever fairy granted. Behold my talisman,'' continued she (fairy), drawing out her (fairy) purse, and showing the gold through the net-work. ``Speak boldly, then,
'' cried she (fairy) to Helena, `and be obeyed.'' (unknown)

``Ah, mamma,'' (Helena/Miss Helena)
said Helena,
``I was not thinking of what fairies or gold can give; but you can grant my wish, and if you will let me, I will whisper it to you.'' (Helena/Miss Helena)

Lady Delacour stooped to hear her (Delacour) daughter's whisper.

``Your wish is granted, my own grateful, charming girl,'' (mother)
said her (Delacour) mother.

Helena's wish was, that her (Delacour) mother could be reconciled to her (Delacour) good aunt, Margaret Delacour.

Her (Delacour) ladyship sat down instantly, and wrote to Mrs Delacour. Helena was the bearer of this letter, and Lady Delacour promised to wait upon this excellent old lady as soon as she (Delacour) should return to town.

In the meantime her (Delacour) ladyship's health rapidly improved under the skilful care of Dr X--: it had been terribly injured by the ignorance and villany of the wretch to whom she (Delacour) had so long and so rashly trusted. The nostrums which he (Delacour) persuaded her (Delacour) to take, and the immoderate use of opium to which she (Delacour) accustomed herself, would have ruined her (Delacour) constitution, had it not been uncommonly strong. Dr X-- recommended it to her (Delacour) ladyship to abstain gradually from opium, and this advice she (Delacour) had the resolution to follow with uninterrupted perseverance.

The change in Lady Delacour's manner of life, in the hours and the company that she (Delacour) kept, contributed much to her (Delacour) recovery. 9 She (Delacour) was no longer in continual anxiety to conceal the state of her (Delacour) health from the world. She (Delacour) had no secret to keep -- no part to act; her (Delacour) reconciliation with her (Delacour) husband and with his (husband) friends restored her (Delacour) mind to ease and self-complacency. Her (Delacour) little Helena was a source of daily pleasure; and no longer conscious of neglecting her (Helena) daughter, she (Helena) no longer feared that the affections of her (Helena) child should be alienated. Dr X--, well aware that the passions have a powerful influence over the body, thought it full as necessary, in some cases, to attend to the mind as to the pulse. By conversing with Lady Delacour, and by combining hints and circumstances, he (husband) soon discovered what had lately been the course of her (Delacour) reading, and what impression it had made on her (Delacour) imagination. Mrs Marriott, indeed, assisted him (husband) with her (Marriott) opinion concerning the methodistical books; and when he (husband) recollected the forebodings of death which her (Marriott) ladyship had felt, and the terror with which she (Marriott) had been seized on the night of Mrs Freke's adventure, he (husband) was convinced that superstitious horrors hung upon his (husband) patient's spirits, and affected her (Freke) health. To argue on religious subjects was not his (husband) province, much less his (husband) inclination; but he (husband) was acquainted with a person qualified by his (husband) profession and his (husband) character `to minister to a mind diseased,'' and he (husband) resolved on the first favourable opportunity to introduce this gentleman to her (Freke) ladyship.

One morning Lady Delacour was complaining to Belinda, that the books in the library were in dreadful confusion.

``My lord has really a very fine library,'' (she)
said she (Delacour); `but I wish he (husband) had half as many books twice as well arranged: I never can find any thing I want. Dr X--, I wish to heaven you could recommend a librarian to my lord -- not a chaplain, observe.''

``Why not a chaplain, may I ask your ladyship?'' (the doctor)
said the doctor.

``Oh, because we had once a chaplain, who gave me a surfeit of the whole tribe. The meanest sycophant, yet the most impertinent busybody -- always cringing, yet always intriguing -- wanting to govern the whole family, and at the same time every creature's humble servant -- fawning to my lord the bishop, insolent to the poor curate -- anathematizing all who differed from him (lord) in opinion, yet without dignity to enforce the respect due to his (lord) faith or his (lord) profession -- greedy for preferment, yet without a thought of the duties of his (lord) office. It was the common practice of this man to leap from his (lord) horse at the church door on a holiday, after following a pack of hounds, huddle on his (lord) surplice, and gabble over the service with the most indecent mockery of religion. Do I speak with acrimony? I have reason. It was this chaplain who first led my lord to Newmarket; it was he (lord) who first taught my lord to drink. Then he (lord) was a wit -- an insufferable wit. His (lord) conversation after he (lord) had drank was such as no woman but Harriot Freke could understand, and such as few gentlemen could hear. I have never, alas! been thought a prude, but in the heyday of my youth and gaiety, this man always disgusted me. In one word, he (man) was a buck parson. I hope you have as great a horror for this species of animal as I have?'' (unknown)

``Full as great,'' (Dr)
replied Dr X--; `but I consider them as monsters, which belonging to no species, can disgrace none.''

``They ought to be hunted by common consent out of civilized society,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)
said Lady Delacour.

``They are by public opinion banished from all rational society; and your ladyship's just indignation proves, that they have no chance of being tolerated by fashion. But would it not allow such beings too much consequence, would it not extend their power to do mischief, if we perceived that one such person could disgust Lady Delacour with the whole race of chaplains?'' (unknown)

``It is uncommon,'' (ladyship)
replied her (Delacour) ladyship, `to hear a physician earnest in the defence of the clergy -- and a literary philosophic physician too! Shall we have an eulogium upon bishops as well as chaplains?''

``We have had that already,'' (Dr)
replied Dr X--.
``All ranks, persuasions, and descriptions of people, including, I hope, those stigmatized by the name of philosophers, have joined in admiration of the bishop of St Pol de Leon. The conduct of the real martyrs to their faith amongst the French clergy, not even the most witty or brutal sceptic could ridicule.'' (unknown)

``You surprise me, doctor!'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)
said Lady Delacour; `for I assure you that you have the character of being very liberal in your opinions.''

``I hope I am liberal in my opinions,'' (the doctor)
replied the doctor, `and that I give your ladyship a proof of it.''

``You would not then persecute a man or woman with ridicule for believing more than you do?'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)
said Lady Delacour.

``Those who persecute, to overturn religion, can scarcely pretend to more philosophy, or more liberality, than those who persecute to support it,'' (Dr)
said Dr X--.

``Perhaps, doctor, you are only speaking popularly?'' (unknown)

``I believe what I now say to be true,'' (Dr)
said Dr X--, ' and I always endeavour to make truth popular.''

``But possibly these are only truths for ladies. Doctor X-- may be such an ungallant philosopher, as to think that some truths are not fit for ladies. He (philosopher) may hold a different language with gentlemen.'' (unknown)

``I should not only be an ungallant but a weak philosopher,'' (Dr)
said Dr X--, `if I thought that truth was not the same for all the world who can understand it. And who can doubt Lady Delacour's being of that number?''

Lady Delacour, who, at the beginning of this conversation, had spoken guardedly, from the fear of lowering the doctor's opinion of her (Delacour) understanding, was put at her (Delacour) ease by the manner in which he (doctor) now spoke; and, half laying aside the tone of raillery, she (Delacour) said to him (doctor),

``Well, doctor! seriously, I am not so illiberal as to condemn all chaplains for one, odious as he (doctor) was. But where to find his (doctor) contrast in these degenerate days? Can you, who are a defender of the faith, and so forth, assist me? Will you recommend a chaplain to my lord?'' (him)

``Willingly,'' (Dr)
said Dr X--; `and that is what I would not say for a world of fees, unless I were sure of my man.''

``What sort of a man is he (man)?'' (unknown)

``Not a buck parson.'' (unknown)

``And I hope not a pedant, not a dogmatist, for that would be almost as bad. Before we domesticate another chaplain, I wish to know all his (chaplain) qualities, and to have a full and true description of him (chaplain).'' (unknown)

``Shall I then give you a full and true description of him (chaplain) in the words of Chaucer?'' (unknown)

``In any words you please. But Chaucer's chaplain must be a little old-fashioned by this time, I should think.'' (unknown)

``Pardon me. Some people, as well as some things, never grow old-fashioned. I should not be ashamed to produce Chaucer's parish priest at this day to the best company in England -- I am not ashamed to produce him (priest) to your ladyship; and if I can remember twenty lines in his (priest) favour, I hope you will give me credit for being a sincere friend to the worthy part of the clergy. Observe, you must take them as I can patch them together; I will not promise that I can recollect twenty lines de suite, and without missing a word; that is what I would not swear to do for His (priest) Grace the Archbishop of Canterbury.'' (unknown)

``His (priest) Grace will probably excuse you from swearing; at least I will,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)

Doctor X--, with sundry intervals of recollection, which may be spared the reader, repeated the following lines:

``Yet has his (priest) aspect nothing of severe But such a face as promised him (priest) sincere, Nothing reserved or sullen was to see, But sweet regards, and pleasing sanctity, Mild was his (priest) accent, and his (priest) action free. With eloquence innate his (priest) tongue was arm'd, Though harsh the precept, yet the preacher charm'd; For, letting down the golden chain from high, He (priest) drew his (priest) audience upwards to the sky. He (priest) taught the Gospel rather than the law, And forced himself to drive, but loved to draw. The tithes his (priest) parish freely paid, he (priest) took; But never sued, or curs'd with bell and book. Wide was his (priest) parish, not contracted close In streets -- but here and there a straggling house. The proud he (priest) tamed, the penitent he (priest) cheer'd, Nor to rebuke the rich offender fear'd. His (priest) preaching much, but more his (priest) practice wrought, A living sermon of the truths he (priest) taught.'' (the reader)
Lady Delacour wished that she (Delacour) could find a chaplain, who in any degree resembled this charming parish priest, and Dr X-- promised that he (priest) would the next day introduce to her (Delacour) his (priest) friend Mr Moreton.

``Mr Moreton!'' (Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)

These circumstances, even if he (Hervey) had not precisely resembled Chaucer's character of a benevolent clergyman, would have strongly interested Lady Delacour in his (Hervey) favour. She (Delacour) found him (Hervey), upon farther acquaintance, a perfect contrast to her (Delacour) former chaplain; and he (chaplain) gradually acquired such salutary influence over her (Delacour) mind, that he (chaplain) relieved her (Delacour) from the terrors of methodism, and in their place substituted the consolations of mild and rational piety.

Her (Delacour) conscience was now at peace; her (Delacour) spirits were real and equable, and never was her (Delacour) conversation so agreeable. Animated with the new feelings of returning health, and the new hopes of domestic happiness, she (Delacour) seemed desirous to impart her (Delacour) felicity to all around her (Delacour), but chiefly to Belinda, who had the strongest claims upon her (Belinda) gratitude, and the warmest place in her (Belinda) affections. Belinda never made her (Belinda) friend feel the weight of any obligation, and consequently Lady Delacour's gratitude was a voluntary pleasure -- not an expected duty. Nothing could be more delightful to Miss Portman than thus to feel herself the object at once of esteem, affection, and respect; to see that she (Portman) had not only been the means of saving her (Portman) friend's life, but that the influence she (Portman) had obtained over her (Portman) mind was likely to be so permanently beneficial both to her (Portman) and to her (Portman) family.

Belinda did not take all the merit of this reformation to herself: she (Belinda) was most willing to share it, in her (Belinda) own imagination, not only with Dr X-- and Mr Moreton, but with poor Clarence Hervey. She (Belinda) was pleased to observe that Lady Delacour never omitted any occasion of doing justice to his (Hervey) merit, and she (Delacour) loved her (Delacour) for that generosity, which sometimes passed the bounds of justice in her (Delacour) eulogiums. But Belinda was careful to preserve her (Belinda) consistency, and to guard her (Belinda) heart from the dangerous effect of these enthusiastic praises; and as Lady Delacour was now sufficiently re-established in her (Delacour) health, she (Delacour) announced her (Delacour) intention of returning immediately to Oakly-park, according to her (Delacour) promise to Lady Anne Percival and to Mr Vincent.

``But, my dear,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)

``Reason! Oh, I have done if you go to reason! Belinda was convinced that, when Lady Delacour had once tasted the pleasures of domestic life, she (Delacour) would not easily return to that dissipation which she (Delacour) had followed from habit, and into which she (Delacour) had first been driven by a mixture of vanity and despair. It was therefore of importance to break at once his (Delacour) connexion with Lord Studley, and to place him (Delacour) in a situation where he (Delacour) might form new habits, and where his (Delacour) dormant talents might be roused to exertion. She (Delacour) was convinced that his (Delacour) understanding was not so much below par as she (Delacour) had once been taught to think it: she (Delacour) perceived, also, that since their reconciliation, Lady Delacour was anxious to make him (Delacour) appear to advantage: whenever he (Delacour) said any thing that was worth hearing, she (Delacour) looked at Belinda with triumph; and whenever he (Delacour) happened to make a mistake in conversation, she (Belinda) either showed involuntary signs of uneasiness, or passed it off with that easy wit, by which she (Belinda) generally knew how `to make the worse appear the better reason.'' Miss Portman knew that Mr Percival possessed the happy talent of drawing out all the abilities of those with whom he (Percival) conversed, and that he (Percival) did not value men merely for their erudition, science, or literature; he (Percival) was capable of estimating the potential as well as the actual range of the mind. Of his (Percival) generosity she (Portman) could not doubt, and she (Portman) was persuaded that he (Percival) would take every possible means which good nature, joined to good sense, could suggest, to raise Lord Delacour in his (Delacour) lady's esteem, and to make that union happy which was indissoluble. All these reflections passed with the utmost rapidity in Belinda's mind, and the result of them was, that she (Belinda) consented to wait Lady Delacour's leisure for her (Delacour) journey.

CHAPTER XXIV

Peu à peu

THINGS were in this situation, when one day Marriott made her (Marriott) appearance at her (Marriott) lady's toilette with a face which at once proclaimed that something had discomposed her (Marriott), and that she (Marriott) was impatient to be asked what it was.

``What is the matter, Marriott?'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)
said Lady Delacour; `for I know you want me to ask.''

``Want you to ask! Oh, dear, my lady, no! -- for I'm sure, it's a thing that goes quite against me to tell; for I thought, indeed, my lady, superiorly of the person in question; so much so, indeed, that I wished what I declare I should now be ashamed to mention, especially in the presence of Miss Portman, who deserves the best that this world can afford of every denomination. Well, ma'am, in one word,'' (she)
continued she (Delacour), addressing herself to Belinda,
``I am extremely rejoiced that things are as they are, though I confess that was not always my wish or opinion, for which I beg Mr Vincent's pardon and yours; but I hope to be forgiven, since I'm now come entirely round to my Lady Anne Percival's way of thinking, which I learnt from good authority at Oakly-park; and I am now convinced and confident, Miss Portman, that every thing is for the best.'' (Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)

``Marriott will inform us, in due course of time, what has thus suddenly and happily converted her (Marriott),'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)

``Dear me! I'm sure I thought we had got rid of all double-dealers, when the house was cleared of Mr Champfort; but, oh, mercy! there's not traps enough in the world for them all; I only wish they were all caught as finely as some people were.

``Tis what all double-dealers, and Champfort at the head of the whole regiment, deserve -- that's certain.'' (unknown)

``We must take patience, my dear Belinda,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)

``Dear! my lady, it has nothing to do with Mr Champfort, nor any such style of personage, I can assure you; for, I'm positive, I'd rather think contemptibly of a hundred million Mr Champforts than of one such gentleman as Mr Clarence Hervey.'' (unknown)

``Clarence Hervey!'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)

``Well, Marriott, what of Mr Hervey?'' (unknown)

It is not, by any means, that I am more of a prude than is becoming, my lady: nor that I take upon me to be so innocent as not to know that young gentlemen of fortune will, if it be only for fashion's sake, have such things as kept mistresses -LRB-begging pardon for mentioning such trash-RRB-; but no one that has lived in the world thinks any thing of that, except,'' (she)

``Then, for mercy's sake, or mine,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)

``Well, my lady, you must know, then, that yesterday I wanted some hempseed for my bullfinch -- Miss Helena's bullfinch, I mean; for it was she (Helena) found it by accident, you know, Miss Portman, the day after we came here. Poor thing! it got itself so entangled in the net over the morello cherry tree, in the garden, that it could neither get itself in nor out; but very luckily Miss Helena saw it, and saved, and brought it in: it was almost dead, my lady.'' (unknown)

``Was it? -- I mean I am very sorry for it: that is what you expect me to say. Now, go on -- get us once past the bullfinch, or tell us what it has to do with Clarence Hervey.'' (unknown)

``That is what I am aiming at, as fast as possible, my lady. So I sent for some hempseed for the bullfinch, and along with the hempseed they brought me wrapped round it, as it were, a printed handbill, as it might be, or advertisement, which I threw off, disregardingly, taking for granted it might have been some of those advertisements for lozenges or razor-strops, that meet one wherever one goes; but Miss Delacour picked it up, and found it was a kind of hue and cry after a stolen or strayed bullfinch. Ma'am, I was so provoked, I could have cried, when I learnt it was the exact description of our little Bobby to a feather -- gray upon the back, and red on -- '

``Oh! spare me the description to a feather. Well, you took the bird, bullfinch, or Bobby, as you call it, home to its rightful owner, I presume? Let me get you so far on your way.'' (unknown)

``No, I beg your pardon, my lady, that is not the thing.'' (unknown)

``Then you did not take the bird home to its owner -- and you are a bird-stealer? With all my heart: be a dog-stealer, if you will -- only go on.'' (unknown)

``And the words were, to leave the bird at a perfumer's in Twickenham, opposite to -- ; but that's no matter. Well, my lady, to the perfumer's I went with the bird, this morning. Now, I had my reasons for wishing to see this Mrs Ormond myself, because, my lady, there was one thing rather remarkable about this bullfinch, that it sings a very particular tune, which I never heard any bullfinch, or any human creature, sing anything like before: so I determined, in my own cogitations, to ask this Mrs Ormond to name the tunes her (Ormond) bullfinch could sing, before I produced it; and if she (Ormond) made no mention of its knowing any one out of the common way, I resolved to keep my bird to myself, as I might very conscientiously and genteelly too. So, my lady, when I got to the perfumer's, I inquired where Mrs Ormond was to be found? I was told that she (Ormond) received no visits from any, at least from the female sex; and that I must leave the bird there till called for. I was considering what to do, and the strangeness of the information made about the female sex, when in there came, into the shop, a gentleman, who saved me all the indelicacy of asking particulars. CHAPTER XXVI

CLARENCE HERVEY``S packet contained a history of his (Vincent) connexion with Virginia St Pierre.

To save our hero from the charge of egotism, we shall relate the principal circumstances in the third person.

It was about a year before he (Vincent) had seen Belinda, that Clarence Hervey returned from his (Hervey) travels; he (Hervey) had been in France just before the Revolution, when luxury and dissipation were at their height in Paris, and when a universal spirit of licentious gallantry prevailed. Some circumstances in which he (Hervey) was personally interested disgusted him (Hervey) strongly with the Parisian belles; he (Hervey) felt that women who were full of vanity, affectation, and artifice, whose tastes were perverted, and whose feelings were depraved, were equally incapable of conferring, or enjoying real happiness. Whilst this conviction was full in his (Hervey) mind, he (Hervey) read the works of Rousseau: this eloquent writer's sense made its full impression upon Clarence's understanding, and his (Clarence) declamations produced more than their just effect upon an imagination naturally ardent. He (Clarence) was charmed with the picture of Sophia, when contrasted with the characters of the women of the world with whom he (Clarence) had been disgusted; and he (Clarence) formed the romantic project of educating a wife for himself. Full of this idea, he (Clarence) returned to England, determined to carry his (Clarence) scheme immediately into execution; but was some time delayed by the difficulty of finding a proper object for his (Clarence) purpose: it was easy to meet with beauty in distress, and ignorance in poverty; but it was difficult to find simplicity without vulgarity, ingenuity without cunning, or even ignorance without prejudice; it was difficult to meet with an understanding totally uncultivated, yet likely to reward the labour of late instruction; a heart wholly unpractised, yet full of sensibility, capable of all the enthusiasm of passion, the delicacy of sentiment, and the firmness of rational constancy. It is not wonderful that Mr Hervey, with such high expectations, should not immediately find them gratified. Disappointed in his (Hervey) first search, he (Hervey) did not, however, relinquish his (Hervey) design, and at length, by accident, he (Hervey) discovered, or thought that he (Hervey) discovered, an object formed expressly for his (Hervey) purpose.

One fine evening in autumn, as he (Hervey) was riding through the New Forest, charmed with the picturesque beauties of the place, he (Hervey) turned out of the beaten road, and struck into a fresh track, which he (Hervey) pursued with increasing delight, till the setting sun reminded him (Hervey), that it was necessary to postpone his (Hervey) further reflections on forest scenery, and that it was time to think of finding his (Hervey) way out of the wood. He (Hervey) was now in the most retired part of the forest, and he (Hervey) saw no path to direct him (Hervey); but, as he (Hervey) stopped to consider which way he (Hervey) should turn, a dog sprang from a thicket, barking furiously at his (Hervey) horse: his (Hervey) horse was high-spirited, but he (Hervey) was master of him (Hervey), and he (Hervey) obliged the animal to stand quietly till the dog, having barked himself hoarse, retreated of his (Hervey) own accord. Clarence watched to see which way he (Clarence) would go, and followed him (Clarence), in hopes of meeting with the person to whom he (Clarence) belonged: he (Clarence) kept his (Clarence) guide in sight, till he (Clarence) came into a beautiful glade, in the midst of which was a neat but very small cottage, with numerous beehives in the garden, surrounded by a profusion of rose-trees, which were in full blow. This cultivated spot was strikingly contrasted with the wildness of the surrounding scenery. As he (Clarence) came nearer, Mr Hervey saw a young girl watering the rose-trees, which grew round the cottage, and an old woman beside her (woman) filling a basket with the flowers. The old woman was like most other old women, except that she (woman) had a remarkably benevolent countenance, and an air that had been acquired in better days; but the young girl did not appear to Clarence like any other young girl that he (Clarence) had ever seen. The setting sun shone upon her (girl) countenance, the wind blew aside the ringlets of her (girl) light hair, and the blush of modesty overspread her (girl) cheeks when she (girl) looked up at the stranger. In her (girl) large blue eyes, there was an expression of artless sensibility, with which Mr Hervey was so powerfully struck that he (Hervey) remained for some moments silent, totally forgetting, that he (Hervey) came to ask his (Hervey) way out of the forest. His (Hervey) horse had made so little noise upon the soft grass, that he (Hervey) was within a few yards of them before he (Hervey) was perceived by the old woman. ``Clarence Hervey?'' (Mrs Ormond/Ormond)
said Mrs Ormond.

``No; still the same figure that knelt to me; and I wished him (Hervey) to be victorious. And he (Hervey) was victorious. CHAPTER XXVII

A Discovery

INSTEAD of the open, childish, affectionate familiarity with which Virginia used to meet Clarence Hervey, she (Ormond) now received him (Hervey) with reserved, timid embarrassment. Struck by this change in her (Ormond) manner, and alarmed by the dejection of her (Ormond) spirits, which she (Ormond) vainly strove to conceal, he (Hervey) eagerly inquired, from Mrs Ormond, into the cause of this alteration.

His (Hervey) indignation was roused by the insult which Virginia had been offered by the strangers who had scaled the garden-wall. Virginia could neither meet his (Hervey) eyes nor speak to him (Hervey) without a degree of embarrassment which she (Ormond) had not sufficient art to conceal: she (Ormond) trembled whenever he (Hervey) came near her (Ormond), and if he (Hervey) looked grave, or forbore to take notice of her (Ormond), she (Ormond) would burst into tears. It was during the time of his (Clarence) passion for her (Ormond) that Clarence had her (Ormond) picture painted in the character of St Pierre's Virginia. It happened to be in the room in which they were now conversing, and when she (Ormond) spoke of loving a life of retirement, Clarence accidentally cast his (Clarence) eyes upon the picture, and then upon Virginia. She (Ormond) turned away -- sighed deeply; and when, in a tone of kindness, he (Clarence) asked her (Ormond) if she (Ormond) were unhappy, she (Ormond) hid her (Ormond) face in her (Ormond) hands, and made no answer.

Mr Hervey could not be insensible to her (Ormond) distress or to her (Ormond) delicacy. He (Hervey) saw her (Ormond) bloom fading daily, her (Ormond) spirits depressed, her (Ormond) existence a burden to her (Ormond), and he (Hervey) feared that his (Hervey) own imprudence had been the cause of all this misery.

``I have taken her (knight) out of a situation in which she (knight) might have spent her (knight) life usefully and happily; I have excited false hopes in her (knight) mind, and now she (knight) is a wretched and useless being. I have won her (knight) affections; her (knight) happiness depends totally upon me; and can I forsake her (knight)? Mrs Ormond says, that she (Ormond) is convinced Virginia would not survive the day of my marriage with another. I am not disposed to believe that girls often die or destroy themselves for love; nor am I a coxcomb enough to suppose that love for me must be extraordinarily desperate. But here's a girl, who is of a melancholy temperament, who has a great deal of natural sensibility, whose affections have all been concentrated, who has lived in solitude, whose imagination has dwelt, for a length of time, upon a certain set of ideas, who has but one object of hope; in such a mind, and in such circumstances, passion may rise to a paroxysm of despair.'' (him)

Pity, generosity, and honour, made him (Hervey) resolve not to abandon this unfortunate girl though he (Hervey) felt that every time he (Hervey) saw Virginia, his (Hervey) love for Belinda increased. It was this struggle in his (Hervey) mind betwixt love and honour which produced all the apparent inconsistency and irresolution that puzzled Lady Delacour and perplexed Belinda. The lock of beautiful hair, which so unluckily fell at Belinda's feet, was Virginia's; he (Hervey) was going to take it to the painter, who had made the hair in her (Belinda) picture considerably too dark. How the picture got into the exhibition must now be explained.

Whilst Mr Hervey's mind was in that painful state of doubt which has just been described, a circumstance happened that promised him (Hervey) some relief from his (Hervey) embarrassment. Mr Hervey now inserted proper advertisements in all the papers, but without producing any effect. Now it happened that the very day when Lady Delacour and Belinda were at the exhibition, the painter called Clarence aside, and informed him (Clarence) that a gentleman had just inquired from him (gentleman) very eagerly, whether the picture of Virginia was a portrait. A Jew

CHAPTER XXXI

The Dénouement

``To Marriott's ruling passion for birds you are all of you indebted for this discovery.
