Now it was believed by the girl of this shop, who had lived for some time with Mrs Ormond -- Forgive me, Mr Hervey, for what I am going to say -- forgive me, Mrs Ormond -- scandal, like death, is common to all -- It was believed that Virginia was Mr Hervey's mistress. My stranger no sooner learned this than he (stranger) swore that he (stranger) would think of her (mistress) no more; and after bestowing a variety of seamen's execrations upon the villain who had seduced this heavenly creature, he (villain) departed from Twickenham, and was no more seen or heard of. My inquiries after him (villain) were indefatigable, but for some time unsuccessful: and so they might have continued, and we might have been all making one another unhappy at this moment, if it had not been for Mr Vincent's great dog Juba -- Miss Annabella Luttridge's billet-doux -- Sir Philip Baddely's insolence -- my Lord Delacour's belief in a quack balsam -- and Captain Sunderland's humanity.'' (unknown)

``Captain Sunderland! who is Captain Sunderland? we never heard of him (Captain) before,'' (Mrs Ormond/Ormond)
cried Mrs Ormond.

``You shall hear of him (Captain) just as I did, if you please,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)
said Lady Delacour, `and if Belinda will submit to hear me tell the same story twice.''

Here her (Belinda) ladyship repeated the history of the battle of the dogs; and of Sir Philip Baddely's knocking down Juba, the man, for struggling in defence of Juba, the dog.

``Now the gentleman who assisted my Lord Delacour in bringing the disabled negro across the square to our house, was Captain Sunderland. My lord summoned Marriott to produce Lady Boucher's infallible balsam, that it might be tried upon Juba's sprained ankle. Whilst my lord was intent upon the balsam, Marriott was intent upon Captain Sunderland. She (Marriott) recollected that she (Marriott) had met him (Captain) somewhere before, and the moment he (Captain) spoke, she (Marriott) knew him (Captain) to be the gentleman who had fallen into ecstasies in the shop at Twickenham, about the bullfinch. Marriott hastened to me with the news; I hastened to my lord, made him (lord) introduce Captain Sunderland to me, and I never rested till he (Captain) had told me all that I wanted to know. Some years ago, just before he (Captain) went to sea, he (Captain) paid a visit to his (Captain) mother, who then lodged with a widow Smith, in the New Forest. Whilst he (Captain) was there, he (Captain) heard of the young beauty who lived in the Forest, with a grandmother, who was not a little particular, and who would not permit any body to see her (grandmother).

``My captain's curiosity was excited; one day, unseen by the duenna, he (captain) obtained a distinct view of Virginia, watering her (grandmother) roses and tending her (grandmother) bees. Struck with her (grandmother) uncommon beauty, he (captain) approached carefully to the thicket in which the cottage was enclosed, and found a lair, where he (captain) concealed himself, day after day, and contemplated at leisure the budding charms of the fair wood-nymph. In short, he (captain) became so enamoured, that he (captain) was determined to gain admittance at the cottage, and declare his (captain) passion: but to his (captain) honour be it told, that when the history of the poor girl's mother, and the situation and fears of the old lady, who was her (lady) only friend, were known to him (friend), in consideration of the extreme youth of the ward, and the extreme age of her (lady) guardian, he (friend) determined to defer his (friend) addresses till his (friend) return from the West Indies, whither he (friend) was shortly to sail, and where he (friend) had hopes of making a fortune, that might put him (friend) in a situation to render the object of his (friend) affections independent. He (friend) left a bullfinch with Mrs Smith, who gave it to Virginia, without telling to whom it had belonged, lest her (Smith) grandmother might be displeased.

``I really thought that all this showed too nice a moral sense for a young dashing lieutenant in the navy, and I was persuaded that my gentleman was only keeping his (gentleman) mistress's secret like a man of honour. With this belief, I regretted that Clarence Hervey should throw himself away upon a girl who was unworthy of him (Hervey).'' (unknown)

``I hope,'' (Clarence Hervey/Mr Hervey/Clarence)
interrupted Clarence, `you are perfectly convinced of your mistake.''

``Perfectly! perfectly! -- I am convinced that Virginia is only half mad. But let me go on with my story. I was determined to discover whether she (girl) had any remains of affection for this captain. It was in vain he (captain) assured me that she (girl) had never seen him (captain). I prevailed upon him (captain) to let me go on my own way. I inquired whether he (captain) had ever had his (captain) picture drawn. Yes, he (captain) had for his (captain) mother, just when he (captain) first went out to sea. It had been left at the widow Smith's. I begged him (captain) to procure it for me. He (captain) told me it was impossible. I told him (captain) I trampled on impossibilities. In short, he (captain) got the picture for me, as you see. ``Now,'' thought I, ``if he (captain) speaks the truth, Virginia will see this picture without emotion, and it will only seem to be a present for Clarence. But if she (Smith) had ever seen him (Clarence) before, or had any secret to conceal, she (Smith) will betray herself on the sudden appearance of this picture.

'' Things have turned out contrary to all my expectations, and yet better. -- And now, Clarence, I must beg you will prevail on Miss Hartley to appear: I can go on no farther without her (Hartley).'' (she)

Lady Delacour took Virginia by the hand, the moment she (Delacour) entered the room.

``Will you trust yourself with me, Miss Hartley?'' (she)
said she (Delacour).
``I have made you faint once to-day by the sight of a picture; will you promise me not to faint again, when I produce the original?'' (unknown)

``The original!'' (unknown)
said Virginia.
``I will trust myself with you, for I am sure you cannot mean to laugh at me, though, perhaps, I deserve to be laughed at.'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)

Lady Delacour threw open the door of another apartment. Mr Hartley appeared, and with him (Hartley) Captain Sunderland.

``My dear daughter,'' (Mr Hartley/Hartley)
said Mr Hartley, `give me leave to introduce to you a friend, to whom I owe more obligations than to any man living, except to Mr Hervey. This gentleman was stationed some years ago at Jamaica, and in a rebellion of the negroes on my plantation he (gentleman) saved my life. Fortune has accidentally thrown my benefactor in my way. To show my sense of my obligations is out of my power.''

Virginia's surprise was extreme; her (gentleman) vivid dreams, the fond wishes of her (gentleman) waking fancy, were at once accomplished. For the first moment she (gentleman) gazed as on an animated picture, and all the ideas of love and romance associated with this image rushed upon her (gentleman) mind.

But when the realities by which he (gentleman) was surrounded dispelled the illusion, she (gentleman) suddenly withdrew her (gentleman) eyes, and blushed deeply, with such timid and graceful modesty as charmed every body present.

Captain Sunderland pressed forward; but was stopped by Lady Delacour.

``Avaunt, thou real lover!'' (she)
cried she (Delacour): `none but the shadow of a man can hope to approach the visionary maid. In vain has Marraton forced his (man) way through the bushes and briars, in vain has he (man) braved the apparition of the lion; there is yet a phantom barrier apparently impassable between him (man) and his (man) Yaratilda, for he (man) is in the world of shadows. Now, mark me, Marraton: hurry not this delicate spirit, or perchance you frighten and lose her (maid) for ever; but have patience, and gradually and gracefully she (maid) will venture into your world of realities -- only give her (maid) time.''

``Time! O yes, give me time,'' (unknown)
cried Virginia, shrinking back.

``My dear Miss Hartley,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)
continued Lady Delacour, `in plain prose, to prevent all difficulties and embarrassments, I must inform you, that Captain Sunderland will not insist upon prompt payment of your father's debt of gratitude: he (Captain) has but one quarter of an hour to spend with us -- he (Captain) is actually under sailing orders; so that you will have time to compose your mind before his (Captain) return. Clarence, I advise you to accompany Captain Sunderland on this cruise; don't you, Belinda?''

``And now, my good friends,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)
continued Lady Delacour, `shall I finish the novel for you?''

``If your ladyship pleases; nobody can do it better,'' (Clarence Hervey/Mr Hervey/Clarence)
said Clarence Hervey.

``But I hope you will remember, dear Lady Delacour,'' (Belinda/Miss Portman/Belinda Portman)
said Belinda, `that there is nothing in which novelists are so apt to err as in hurrying things toward the conclusion: in not allowing time enough for that change of feeling, which change of situation cannot instantly produce.''

``That's right, my dear Belinda; true to your principles to the last gasp. Fear nothing -- you shall have time enough to become accustomed to Clarence. Would you choose that I should draw out the story to five volumes more? With your advice and assistance, I can with the greatest ease, my dear. A declaration of love, you know, is only the beginning of things; there may be blushes, and sighs, and doubts, and fears, and misunderstandings, and jealousies without end or common sense, to fill up the necessary space, and to gain the necessary time; but if I might conclude the business in two lines, I should say,

``Ye gods, annihilate both space and time, And make four lovers happy.'' (unknown)
'
``Oh, that would be cutting matters too short,'' (Mrs Delacour/Mrs Margaret Delacour/Margaret)
said Mrs Margaret Delacour.
``I am of the old school; and though I could dispense with the description of Miss Harriot Byron's worked chairs and fine china, yet I own I like to hear something of the preparations for a marriage, as well as of the mere wedding. I like to hear how people become happy in a rational manner, better than to be told in the huddled style of an old fairy tale -- and so they were all married, and they lived very happily all the rest of their days.'' (unknown)

``We are not in much danger of hearing such an account of modern marriages,'' (Lady Delacour/Delacour/lady Delacour)
said Lady Delacour. ``But how shall I please you all? -- Some people cry,
``Tell me every thing;'' (unknown)
others say, that,

``Le secret d'ennuyer est eclui de tout dire.'' (me)
``Something must be left to the imagination. Positively I will not describe wedding-dresses, or a procession to church. I have no objection to saying that the happy couple were united by the worthy Mr Moreton; that Mr Percival gave Belinda away; and that immediately after the ceremony, he (Percival) took the whole party down with him (Percival) to Oakly-park. Will this do? -- Or, we may conclude, if you like it better, with a characteristic letter of congratulation from Mrs Stanhope to her (Stanhope) dearest niece, Belinda, acknowledging that she (Belinda) was wrong to quarrel with her (Belinda) for refusing Sir Philip Baddely, and giving her (Belinda) infinite credit for that admirable management of Clarence Hervey, which she (Belinda) hopes will continue through life.'' (unknown)

``Well, I have no objection to ending with a letter,'' (Mrs Delacour/Mrs Margaret Delacour/Margaret)
said Mrs Delacour; `for last speeches are always tiresome.''

``Yes,'' (ladyship)
said her (Delacour) ladyship; `it is so difficult, as the Critic says, to get lovers off upon their knees. Now I think of it, let me place you all in proper attitudes for stage effect. What signifies being happy, unless we appear so? -- Captain Sunderland -- kneeling with Virginia, if you please, sir, at her (Delacour) father's feet: you in the act of giving them your blessing, Mr Hartley. Mrs Ormond clasps her (Ormond) hands with joy -- nothing can he (Hartley) better than that, madam -- I give you infinite credit for the attitude. Clarence, you have a right to Belinda's hand, and may kiss it too: nay, Miss Portman, it is the rule of the stage. Now, where's my Lord Delacour? he (Delacour) should be embracing me, to show that we are reconciled. Ha! here he (Delacour) comes -- Enter Lord Delacour, with little Helena in his (Delacour) hand -- very well! a good start of surprise, my love -- stand still, pray; you cannot be better than you are: Helena, my love, do not let go your father's hand. There! quite pretty and natural! Now, Lady Delacour, to show that she (Delacour) is reformed, comes forward to address the audience with a moral -- a moral! Yes,

``Our tale contains a moral; and, no doubt You all have wit enough to find it out.'' (unknown)
'

Notes:

1 This declaration was taken from the lips of a celebrated character.

2The manners, if not the morals, of gentlemen, have improved since the first publication of this work. Swearing has gone out of fashion. But Sir Philip Baddely's oaths are retained, as marks in a portrait of the times held up to the public, touched by ridicule, the best reprobation.

3The bloody hand is the heraldic designation of the baronet.

4

``Would Chloe know if you're alive or dead, She (Belinda) bids her (Belinda) footman put it in her (Belinda) head.'' (unknown)

5 See Adventures of a Guinea, vol. i, chap xvi.

6 Marmontel.

7 See Edward's History of the West Indies, vol. ii.

8 Miscellaneous Pieces by Mrs Barbauld and Dr Aikin.

9 We spare the reader the medical journal of Lady Delacour's health for some months. Her (Delacour) recovery was gradual and complete.

10 A fact.
